_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Environmental Protection Agency Risk Management Plan

Enterprise Kearney Terminal & Storage

Risk Management Plan (RMP)

Executive Summary



At the Enterprise Kearney Terminal and Storage, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment.



The Enterprise Kearney Terminal and Storage is owned by Enterprise Terminals & Storage, LLC, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Mapletree, LLC, and operated by Enterprise Products Operating L.P. (Enterprise).



We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help provide for the safety of our employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the risk management measures that we have designed and implemented, including:



* A description of our facility and use of substances required by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) RMP regulation and the processes involved

* A summary of results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences from accidental chemical releases

* Emergency Response Programs

* General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

* A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals at the Kearney Terminal that are regulated by EPA?s RMP rule.  



Facility Description



The Kearney Terminal is a liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) pipeline and propane storage/loading facility.  The process is regulated by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration under 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR Part 68.  We have entered the facility as an RMP Program Level 3 facility.



The Kearney Terminal has two Department of Transportation ? regulated pip

elines that are routed through the facility.  One pipeline is a mixed product line while the other pipeline is a dedicated propane line of which the facility receives propane from the pipeline to one 90,000 gallon capacity storage tank and two 63,000 gallon capacity tanks.  These tanks are used for distribution to the truck transport loading docks which also has capabilities to stench the propane for retail sales companies.  All of these tanks are administratively controlled to hold and not exceed 85% of their capacity.



In our process we use the following chemicals that the EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequence in the event of a substantial accidental release:



Toxics



No toxic materials to report.



Flammables



Propane is delivered into three storage tanks via the dedicated propane pipeline.  This material is routed from these tanks to the four truck transport loading docks for wholesale distribution to propane retailers.



Ethyl Mercaptan is used to stench the propane at the truck transport docks.



Key Offsite Consequence Analysis Scenarios



The EPA's RMP rule requires that we provide information about the worst-case scenarios(s) and alternative release scenario(s) for our facility.  The following are brief summaries of these scenarios, including information about the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the exposure distances for each scenario.



Worst Case Release Scenario ? Regulated Toxic Chemical



There are no regulated toxic chemicals to report for the Kearney Terminal.



Alternate Release Scenario(s) ? Regulated Toxic Chemical



There are no regulated toxic chemicals to report for the Kearney Terminal.



Worse Case Scenario ? Regulated Flammable Chemicals



This simulation involves the rupture or failure of the propane storage tanks resulting in a simulated vapor cloud explosion.  The entire inventories from all three tanks are simulated due to the proximity of the t

anks relative to mitigation to the simulation.  This scenario assumes there would be no mitigation.  All emergency response and early warning procedures to inform employees and the community would be exercised immediately if this were to occur.  The quantity and endpoint of the simulation and the specifics of the simulation are available in the specified reporting of the Risk Management Plan



Alternate Case Scenario ? Regulated Flammable Chemicals



The alternate release scenario is a simulated rupture of the supply pipe to the loading docks resulting in a ten minute release and simulated vapor cloud explosion.  This scenario assumed the pump continued to operate at a rate of approximately 500 gallons per minutes (gpm) for 10 minutes after the line break.  The simulation calculated that 21,267 pounds of material were released in the assumed time frame.  Mitigation measures were taken into account when selecting the alternative release scenario.  These measures consisted of reviewing the use of relief valves, check valves, manual shutoff valves, automatic shutoffs, startup and operating procedures, grounding equipment, and excess flow devices.  Activation of the Emergency Shutdown Devices would isolate the source of the material and secure the facility.  All emergency response and early warning procedures to inform employees and the community would be exercised immediately if this were to occur.  The quantity and endpoint of the simulation is contained in the data elements.



We are using this information to help us ensure that our emergency response plan and the community emergency response plan address a reasonable range of contingencies.



Emergency Response Program



Enterprise maintains an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning and reporting.  The program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, a

nd the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, the plan is coordinated with the City of Kearny and Clay County LEPC who dispatches the necessary Kearney Police, Clay County Sheriff?s Department, Kearney Fire Department, and Emergency Medical Service.



In the event of an accidental release, local Enterprise personnel are trained to sound the alarm, shut off the source from a safe location or activate the emergency shutdown system, contact 9-1-1 and secure the area.  The 9-1-1 system will be used to notify the City of Kearney Emergency Communications Center which will make notification to the local law enforcement and Fire Department(s).  Remote activation can also be accomplished from Enterprise?s Houston Control which has area video cameras with dial-up access.  In addition, there are local gas detection systems that alarm locally and in Houston Control.  If these detectors annunciate, the facility can be shut down remotely from Houston Control or locally by operations personnel.  A third-party contractor, 3E Company is under contract to contact the necessary agencies if required.  



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



Enterprise takes a systematic, protective approach to preventing accidental release of hazardous chemicals.  Our Process Safety Management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention program, including:



* Process safety information

* Process hazard analysis

* Operating procedures

* Training

* Mechanical integrity

* Management of change

* Pre-Startup Safety Review - "PSSR"

* Compliance audits

* Incident investigation

* Employee participation

* Hot work permit

* Contractors



As a part of our prevention efforts, Enterprise employees participate in numerous safety and training programs.  A training program has been developed in which Operations and Maintenance personnel are specifically trained in the operation of the facility, the operating proced

ures, maintenance procedures, and specific other regulations and policies, as well as in all areas of emergency response.  Employees are trained on, use, and apply the guidelines of our PSM program, which include all of the above-listed areas.  All of these programs come under scheduled scrutiny and critique.



There is an on-going inspection program designed to search out and find deficiencies with the process equipment prior to any incident.



Operations personnel make regular inspections of the equipment and processes they operate.  If something out of the ordinary is found, it is reported to management in order to expediently resolve any problems.



The engineering and administrative controls in place have been established to reduce the risk of an accidental release of identified hazards.  Enterprise is committed to operations that are safe for employees and the surrounding community.



Accident History



Records are kept for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  The following is a brief summary of accidental chemical releases involving materials covered under EPA's RMP rule during the past five years:



Based on the criteria set forth in 40 CFR 68.10, this facility has not had an accidental release.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



The following is a list of improvements that are planned for implementation at the facility to help prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:



* The PSM system is constantly being subjected to critical reviews with an objective of improving the programs.

* The written PSM management system is presently undergoing a review, with specific emphasis being placed on the written mechanical integrity program.

* The Emergency Preparedness Plan is presently being reviewed and updated and will be coordinated with local officials when complete.

* The Safety Procedures and Policies Manual is presently being reviewed and updated and should be completed in the fall of 2005.
